#Text=Douz
#Text=Douz is a small town in south-central of Tunisia .
#Text=Referred to as the " Gateway to the Sahara " , Douz is a popular destination for tourists looking to experience the desert , either by camel or four-wheel drive .

column1: #Text=Understand
#Text=The town of Douz has grown up around a large palm oasis that stands on the northern fringe of the Sahara .
#Text=Surrounded by little other than desert and dry scrub land , historically it was an important stop on the trans-Saharan caravan routes .
#Text=Today tourists come in numbers , many on organized coach tours from the coastal resorts , to get a taste of the mighty Sahara for themselves .
#Text=Get in
#Text=By car , Douz is about 1hr30m drive west of Matmata on a good road , or 2hr to the east of Tozeur .
#Text=Much of the drive from Tozeur is along a causeway that crosses the Chott El-Jerid , a vast lake covered in a thick crust of dried salt .
#Text=See
#Text=The annual International Festival of the Sahara .
#Text=Held towards the end of each year , the four day festival showcases the local desert culture , including camel and horse riding displays , poetry readings and traditional music and dance .

#Text=The Museum of the Sahara - a small but interesting collection portraying traditional Saharan life where the founder and curator , who 's also a popular local poet , will courteously and patiently give you a fascinating tour of the collection .
#Text=Open Tu - Su 9:30AM-4:30PM .
#Text=Do
#Text=Take a camel trip out into the Sahara with one of the many tour operators based in the town center .
#Text=Other tours into the desert can be arranged , including by motorbike or 4-Wheel-Drive , usually by the same tour operators .
#Text=Visit the Chott al-Jerid .
#Text=A vast dry salt lake with a thick crust of salt which sparkles in the sun .
#Text=Look closely and you may see some mirages .
#Text=Buy
#Text=Through the main square , where all the tourist wares are on display , and into the small bustling local market for fruit and veg , dates and olives , bread etc for your daily picnic .
#Text=Eat
#Text=You can find good restaurants and cafés in Douz , ( e.g. café of glissia " grandes dunes in " zone touristique " " ) or eat in hotels .
#Text=There are 6 large hotels in Douz in the tourist zone , or you could even go into the desert and make the sand bread " Mella " with dates !
#Text=Drink
#Text=Mint tea is a local speciality .
#Text=Sleep
#Text=If you take an overnight camel trek , you will get to sleep out in the desert ( and hence save the cost of a night 's accommodation ! ) .
#Text=Be warned though - despite pictures in the tour offices of luxury Bedouin style tents , in practice the shelter is somewhat more basic and bathroom facilities may be somewhat primitive .
#Text=Still , it is a great experience with campfire , ad hoc drumming/dancing sessions , fire-baked flat bread for breakfast and camel treks back to town the following morning .

#Text=Hotel 20 Mars is reasonably priced , very clean and relaxed , with simpler rooms downstairs and en-suite rooms on the first-floor all around a cool , pretty courtyard for breakfast , snacks and games of chess .
